front.title: Checksum Compensation Options for UDP Options

abstract.t: This document describes a robust method for calculating checksums for use with UDP Options.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: UDP Options adds support for transport options in UDP . When UDP is carried in IP two lengths describing the UDP datagram, the IP transport carries a payload length and the UDP header carries the length of the UDP datagram. Most of the time today IP payload length is equal to the UDP length, UDP Options creates a surplus area by adding increasing the IP payload length while not varying the UDP length. Transport Options are then added in this surplus area in the form of a TLV encoded list.

UDP datagrams with surplus data are a new in the network, many network devices assume that IP payload length is equal to UDP length and have used this value when calculating UDP checksums. This leads to many network devices incorrectly calculating the UDP checksum when forwarding packets leading to UDP datagrams with Options being dropped by these devices.
This document describes common pathologies of network devices which incorrectly calculate the UDP checksum and proposes a new UDP Option to compensate for incorrect UDP checksum calculation.

section.title: Middlebox Pathologies
section.t: Middleboxes and network interfaces can compute UDP Checksum incorrectly in presence of UDP Options based on the assumption that IP Payload Length and UDP Length coincide (an assumption that was reasonable before UDP Options).
They middleboxes use the IP Payload Length (obtained as IP Total Length - IP Header Length) to fill UDP pseudo-header Length and also computes the checksum over the all IP Payload bytes.
This can lead to UDP Options packets with correct checksum to be discarded by end-hosts or by middleboxes along the path.
shows UDP Checksum computation based on UDP Length and based on IP Payload Length and the fields which differ between the two calculation methods.

section.title: Checksum Compensation Option
section.t: The purpose of CCO is to increase UDP Options compatibility with middleboxes and other existing network equipment, while at the same time providing error detection on UDP Options area in the same way UDP Checksum provides it on UDP Header and UDP Payload.

CCO provides a way for UDP Option packets to be compatible with both checksum computations making UDP Checksum computed on the whole IP Payload coincide with the one correctly computed on the sole UDP Length.

The Checksum Compensation Option (CCO) is the 2 byte one's complement of the one's complement sum of all 2 byte words in the UDP Options. UDP Options area is divided into 2 byte words based on the their alignment with the first byte of UDP packet (and not the first byte of UDP Options). This means that the first and the last byte of UDP Options may be not preceded or followed by another byte: in these cases the unpaired byte must padded respectively on the left and on the right with zero to form a 2 byte word.

section.title: Interaction with other UDP Options
section.t:
Interaction with other UDP Options
Similarly to what happens with OCS, AE can be computed as if the AE hash and CCO value are zero. CCO value can be computed as if the CCO value is zero and after the AE hash has been computed.
CCO has no interference with ACS since ACS is computed only on UDP Payload bytes (no Header, no Options). The CCO value must be computed after ACS has already been computed.
CCO covers the entire UDP Option area, including LITE option as formatted after swapping (or relocation) for transmission (or, equivalently, before the swap/relocation after reception). CCO is computed after LITE swapping/relocation in order to guarantee the checksum compensation of the packet actually sent.
